unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from gray’s anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, © 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

unit 5 overview previous next the skeleton is quite sensibly divided into an axial division and an appendicular division. the axial division consists of the skull, vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 1, you were introduced to the vertebral column and bony thorax. in unit 2, you learned the anatomy of the skull. in unit 3, you studied the appendicular division of the skeleton, including the pectoral girdle and upper limb, and the pelvic girdle and lower limb. in addition, you learned the fascial compartments of the limbs and the peripheral vascular system. now, in cpc-3, unit 5, you will learn the anatomy of the musculoskeletal system, including the articulations , movements, major muscles and nerves of the limbs.

lab 15 instructions previous take me to exercise selection prior to lab 15, complete exercise 15a, a short self-learning module that introduces you to the innervation of the limbs. the lab will begin with an app-based quiz on this slm. lab 15 includes four exercises that describe the nerves of the proximal limbs and the articulations of the distal limbs. prior to the lab, you must review the content of exercises 15.1 - 15.4 so that your time in lab is used efficiently. the material for these exercises will be placed at four different stations around your lab room. you will work and rotate with your pairs: 15.5 is a field trip to grant’s museum, where there are outstanding dissections of musculoskeletal anatomy, including the deep musculature of the back. take time to study these specimens. 9:00-10:30 10:30-12:00 12:00-1:00 1:00-2:30 2:30-4:00 15.1 group 1 group 4 lunch group 3 group 2 15.2 group 2 group 1 lunch group 4 group 3 15.3 group 3 group 2 lunch group 1 group 4 15.4 group 4 group 3 lunch group 2 group 1

using the emodule previous next use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe next, or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe previous or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 15 exercise 15a pre-lab 15.1 the brachial 15.2 nerves

previous got it, let’s move on conventions used in the emodule tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k with age, wear and tear, info an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related slides. click the icon to return. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts

lab 15 exercise selection select an exercise to begin: lab 15 exercises 15.1 the brachial plexus 15.1 the brachial plexus 15.1 the brachial plexus 15.2 nerves of the arm 15.2 nerves of the arm 15.2 nerves of the arm 15.3 nerves of the hip and thigh 15.3 nerves of the hip and thigh 15.3 nerves of the hip and thigh 15.4 distal limb articulations 15.4 distal limb articulations 15.4 distal limb articulations if you finish early… 15.5 field trip 15.5 field trip 15.5 field trip review lab 15 quizlandia 15 quizlandia 15 quizlandia 15 pre-lab slm 15a innervation of the limbs 15a innervation of the limbs 15a innervation of the limbs

15a innervation of the limbs back to exercise selection next objectives: when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the transitional zones of the upper and lower limbs. describe the functions of peripheral nerves of the upper and lower limbs. define the term “compound nerve” and understand their relationship to spinal nerves. describe the motor and sensory distribution of the major nerves of the shoulder and arm, hip and thigh. describe those regions of the limbs where nerves are vulnerable to damage, and where therefore common peripheral neuropathies occur.

15a transitional zones of the upper limb the axilla is bounded by muscles and bones of the upper limb and thorax. all major neurovascular structures that pass between the neck or thorax and the upper limb must pass through the axilla. the cubital fossa is located anterior to the elbow, and is bounded by muscles of the forearm. it contains the primary blood vessel that supplies the forearm, as well as a major nerve. the carpal tunnel is located anterior to the radiocarpal joint. its walls are formed by the carpal bones and by a ligament that connects them. it contains the long flexor tendons destined to control the fingers, as well as a major nerve. as you learn the nerve supply to the upper limb, and connect this information with what you already know about its blood supply and venous drainage, these transitional zones will gain importance. 2 previous next major blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics group together to pass through transitional zones between the regions of the upper limb.

15a introduction: innervation of the upper limb nerves of the upper limb serve three broad purposes: i) they control skeletal muscles (somatic motor fibres) so as to allow us to position and manipulate our hands, ii) they provide sensory feedback to the cns (sensory fibres) which, in turn, informs our movements, amongst other functions, iii) they control vascular resistance and sweating, and therefore the distribution of blood to skeletal muscle and skin as well as body temperature (sympathetic postganglionic fibres). because these nerves contain both motor and sensory fibres, they are called mixed nerves. the peripheral nerves of the upper limb are derived from the brachial plexus, which is itself formed from the ventral rami of five spinal nerves, c5 - t1. the brachial plexus forms in the neck and passes posterior to the clavicle into the axilla. the blood supply to the upper limb is derived from the subclavian artery, which emerges from the thoracic outlet (superior thoracic aperture) to enter the axilla, where its name changes to the axillary artery. venous blood drains away from the upper limb via the axillary vein, which becomes the subclavian vein and then enters the thorax via the superior thoracic aperture. 3 previous next

15a peripheral nerves are compound nerves each spinal nerve carries information associated with a single spinal level , as do their dorsal and ventral rami. each ventral ramus associated with the brachial plexus (c5-t1), therefore, delivers fibres from a single spinal level into the plexus. the ventral rami of the c5-t1 spinal nerves form the roots of the brachial plexus. 4 previous next the roots coalesce and then divide, and then coalesce and divide one more time to give rise to the peripheral nerves of the upper limb. when they coalesce, fibres from different spinal levels combine, and therefore, peripheral nerves are often compound nerves, i.e. they contain fibres from multiple spinal levels.

15a motor distribution of peripheral nerves you are familiar with the compartments of the arm from unit 3. if you need reminding, click here: . each compartment of the arm is associated with a dominant movement: muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm flex the elbow, while muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm extend the elbow. 5 previous next fortunately for us, trying to learn the relationships between peripheral nerves and movements, all the muscles in each of the two compartments of the arm are innervated by one of the major peripheral nerves derived from the brachial plexus. the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve, and the muscles of the posterior compartment of the arm are innervated by the radial nerve. the axillary nerve innervates the deltoid muscle which clothes the lateral aspect of the shoulder and acts to abduct the glenohumeral joint. the median and ulnar nerves pass through the anterior compartment of the arm on their way to the forearm and hand, where they reach their target muscles.

15a sensory distribution of peripheral nerves as you know, the major branches of the brachial plexus carry sensory fibres as well as motor fibres. each of them has a region of skin in the upper arm for which they are responsible. since they are compound nerves, their area of distribution includes portions of multiple dermatomes. the axillary nerve monitors the skin of the lateral aspect of the shoulder. the radial nerve monitors the skin of the posterior arm, forearm and lateral hand. the musculocutaneous nerve monitors the skin of the lateral forearm. the median nerve monitors the skin of the palmar surface of the hand and lateral three and a half digits. the ulnar nerve innervates the medial hand and one-and-a-half digits. 6 previous next

15a peripheral nerves vulnerable to damage with traumatic injury some peripheral nerves, at certain points during their course through the upper limb, are closely applied to bone. traumatic injury in these areas can result in nerve damage with stereotyped motor and sensory signs . the axillary nerve is closely associated with the surgical neck of the humerus and is vulnerable here. while this is the most common site of humeral fracture, which may damage the axillary nerve, the nerve is more commonly damaged with a dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. in the arm, the radial nerve runs obliquely across the posterior aspect of humerus along the spiral (radial) groove , and the radial nerve is vulnerable here, in fractures of the midshaft of the humerus. at the elbow, the ulnar nerve passes posterior to the medial epicondyle, where it is vulnerable to fracture or compression. 7 previous next

15a transitional zones of the lower limb major blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics group together to pass through transitional zones between the regions of the lower limb. the femoral triangle, which is bounded by the inguinal ligament, superiorly, and by muscles of the anterior thigh, inferiorly, connects the abdomen and pelvis with the anterior thigh. the popliteal fossa, located posterior to the knee, connects the posterior thigh and the leg. the tarsal tunnel, posteroinferior to the medial malleolus, connects the leg and foot. as you learn the nerve supply to the lower limb, and connect this information with what you know about its blood supply and venous drainage, these transitional zones will gain importance. 8 previous next

15a introduction: innervation of the lower limb 9 previous next the peripheral nerves of the lower limb are derived from the lumbar and sacral plexuses, which are formed from the ventral rami of lumbar and sacral spinal nerves. the lumbar plexus (l1-l4) forms in the posterior abdominal wall, and the sacral plexus (l4-s4) forms in the pelvis. they give rise to the peripheral nerves that innervate the lower limb those that innervate the abdominal wall and perineum. the blood supply to the lower limb is derived from the external iliac artery, which passes from the false pelvis, under the inguinal ligament, to become the femoral artery. venous blood drains from the lower limb via the femoral vein, which passes under the inguinal ligament to become the external iliac vein in the false pelvis. nerves of the lower limb serve three broad purposes: i) they control skeletal muscles (somatic motor fibres) so as to allow us to walk or ride a bike, for instance, i) they provide sensory feedback to the cns (sensory fibres) which, in turn, informs our movements, and iii) they control vascular resistance and sweat glands, and therefore the distribution of blood to skeletal muscle and skin as well as body temperature (sympathetic postganglionic fibres).

15a peripheral nerves are compound nerves each spinal nerve carries information associated with a single spinal level , as do their dorsal and ventral rami. each ventral ramus associated with the lumbar or sacral plexuses, therefore, delivers fibres from a single spinal level into the plexus. the ventral rami, or branches of them, coalesce to give rise to the peripheral nerves of the lower limb. when they coalesce, fibres from different spinal levels combine, and therefore peripheral nerves of the limbs are compound nerves, i.e. they contain fibres from multiple spinal levels. 10 previous next

15a motor distribution of peripheral nerves to the thigh you are familiar with the compartments of the thigh from unit 3. if you need reminding, click here . each compartment of the thigh is associated with a dominant movement: muscles of the anterior compartment of the thigh (the quadriceps) predominantly extend the knee, while muscles of the posterior compartment of the thigh (the hamstrings) predominantly flex the knee. the muscles of the medial compartment (the adductors) of the thigh predominantly adduct the hip. fortunately for us, trying to learn the relationships between peripheral nerves and movements, each compartment contains a different peripheral nerve, and therefore each movement is also associated with a different peripheral nerve. 11 previous next from the lumbar plexus, the femoral nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior (extensor) compartment of the thigh, and the obturator nerve innervates most of the muscles in the medial (adductor) compartment of the thigh. from the sacral plexus, the sciatic nerve innervates the muscles of the posterior (flexor) compartment of the thigh.

15a sensory distribution of peripheral nerves to the thigh as you know, peripheral nerves carry sensory fibres as well as motor fibres. each of them has a region of skin for which they are responsible. from the lumbar plexus: the femoral nerve monitors the skin of the anterior thigh. the obturator nerve monitors skin of the medial thigh. the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh monitors the skin of the lateral thigh. from the sacral plexus: the posterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh monitors the skin of the posterior thigh. 12 previous next

15a quiz start 13 previous you’ve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the end-of-exercise quiz now? hmmm, why not? go to the quiz sorry, busy now. i’m setting up a date for tonight. skip the quiz

15.1 the brachial plexus back to station selection resources articulated bony arm prosected specimens demonstrating i) the pectoral region ii) the brachial plexus next
when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe the structure and contents of the axilla, including the brachial plexus. 15.1 objectives 2 previous next

15.1 the axilla the axilla is a pyramidally-shaped region that provides continuity between the neck / thorax and the upper limb. like any quadrilateral pyramid, the axilla has a base, four walls and an apex . 3 previous next the apex of the axilla is posterior to the clavicle. here, arteries, veins, nerves and lymphatics pass into / out of the axilla. the base of the axilla includes the skin of the armpit and an opening, lateral to it, that is continuous with the anterior compartment of the arm. the walls of the axilla are irregularly-shaped, and are composed of a combination of bones and muscles. the axilla has medial, lateral, anterior and posterior walls .

15.1 walls of the axilla i 4 previous next unwrap the specimen labelled “pectoral region”. tas k follow the pectoralis major to the anterior aspect of the proximal humerus. follow the pectoralis minor to the coracoid process of the scapula. when covered with skin, these form the anterior axillary fold. flex your shoulder against resistance to contract the pectoralis major . identify, by palpation, your own anterior axillary fold. on the specimen, identify the medial wall of the axilla, made up of the lateral thoracic wall clothed by the serratus anterior muscle. moisten the specimen and drape it with a damp cloth . identify the muscles that make up the anterior wall of the axilla, the pectoralis major and minor muscles.

the lateral wall of the axilla is long and narrow; it is the floor of the intertubercular groove of the humerus. on the specimen, identify the borders of the intertubercular groove as follows: it is bordered medially by the tendon of insertion of the latissimus dorsi, and laterally by the tendon of insertion of the pectoralis major. on the brachial plexus specimen, the tendon of insertion of the pectoralis major will be cut. the structures forming the walls of the axilla are again summarized here: 15.1 walls of the axilla ii 5 previous next identify the serratus anterior muscle on the lateral thoracic wall, making up the medial wall of the axilla . unwrap the specimen labelled “brachial plexus”. tas k now, identify the structures that make up the posterior wall of the axilla, the scapula clothed in the subscapularis, the teres major muscle and the latissimus dorsi muscle. when covered with skin, these form the posterior axillary fold. identify, by palpation, your own posterior axillary fold .

15.1 the floor of the axilla 6 previous next between the anterior axillary skin fold and the posterior axillary skin fold is a dome of skin and underlying fascia that we colloquially call our “armpit”. abduct your arm and palpate your armpit between the anterior and posterior walls of the axilla. the contents of the axillary skin folds, their contained muscles, continue toward the humerus, beyond the lateral extreme of the armpit, to their points of insertion. lateral to this dome of skin, between the converging tendons of the pectoralis major and the latissimus dorsi, structures pass between the axilla and the anterior compartment of the arm. these structures include nerves, arteries, veins and lymphatics, enclosed within the axillary sheath.

15.1 the contents of the axilla the axilla contains the major arteries, veins, nerves, lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes of the upper limb. the axillary tail of the breast extends into the axilla, around the inferior border of the pectoralis major. the breast has been removed from the prosected specimen. recall that normally, i.e. in the non-cancerous breast, the majority of the lymph from the breast drains to axillary lymph nodes. 7 previous next prosection. there, identify the cut tendon of the pectoralis minor. identify the two muscles of the arm that originate here, the coracobrachialis and the short head of the biceps brachii. identify the coracoid process in the brachial plexus tas k also, as you will learn, two muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm extend through the axilla from their origin at the coracoid process to their points of insertion.

15.1 arteries of the axilla on the accompanying diagram, note that the subclavian artery becomes the axillary artery as it passes into the axilla. as it then passes from the axilla into the anterior compartment of the arm, it becomes the brachial artery. note also that the brachial artery gives one major branch in the arm, the deep brachial artery, which passes posterior to the humerus into the posterior compartment of the arm. the brachial plexus prosection you have been given may, or may not, have the axillary artery. if it does, 8 previous next subclavian artery, the axillary artery, the brachial artery and the deep brachial artery. if it does not, go to grant’s identify the tas k museum of anatomy and look at it there. realize that the walls of the axilla are supplied by various branches of the axillary artery.

15.1 veins and lymph nodes of the axilla i veins and lymph nodes will have been removed from the prosection of the axilla, but they must not be overlooked. deep veins of the axilla are the companions of, and take the same name as, the arteries described. the superficial veins of the upper limb, you will recall from unit 3, are the cephalic vein, on the lateral aspect of the hand, forearm and arm, and the basilic vein, on the medial aspect of the hand, forearm and arm. 9 previous next

15.1 veins and lymph nodes of the axilla ii 1. humeral nodes, located posterior to the brachial vein, process most lymph from the upper limb. 2. pectoral nodes receive lymph from the anterior wall of the axilla, the abdomen, chest, and breast. 3. subscapular nodes receive lymph from the posterior wall of the axilla, the shoulder, back and neck. 4. central nodes are embedded within the adipose of the axilla, and receive lymph from these three groups of nodes. 6. apical nodes receive lymph from the central nodes, from upper portions of the breast, and from the: 5. infraclavicular nodes, which are associated with the terminus of the cephalic vein. efferent lymphatics vessels from the apical nodes form the subclavian trunk (7), which ultimately empties into blood at the venous angles. 10 previous next axillary lymph nodes are commonly divided into five or six groups: the relationship between nodes 1 through 4 are illustrated nicely here:

15.1 the brachial plexus i read the following with reference to the schematic diagram. note the ventral rami of c5-t1 form the roots of the brachial plexus. roots coalesce to form trunks, which bifurcate to form divisions. divisions coalesce to form cords, which give rise to the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb. at points of branching and coalescing, fibres from different spinal levels are intermingled. the brachial plexus arises in the neck superior and posterior to the subclavian artery. as it passes into the axilla, its cords surround the axillary artery, and take their names from their position relative to the axillary artery; thus they are the medial, lateral and posterior cords. now turn your attention to the prosection of the brachial plexus. it may, or may not, have the axillary artery intact. if it does, gently move it to the side, as needed, to see the components described. 11 previous next the brachial plexus is the somatic plexus of the upper limb, arising in the neck from the ventral rami of c5-t1. in addition to somatic motor and sensory fibres, it contains sympathetic postganglionic fibres contributed by grey rami communicantes from the sympathetic chain. it gives rise to the peripheral nerves that supply the shoulder region, arm, forearm and hand.

15.1 the brachial plexus ii to where they combine as the inferior trunk. identify the middle trunk, and confirm that it is simply the continuation of the c7 root . continuing distally, confirm that each of the three trunks bifurcate to form divisions, designated anterior and posterior. identify the posterior cord and confirm that it is formed by the union of the three posterior divisions. the posterior cord gives rise to a nerve that is contained within the posterior compartments of the arm and forearm. follow the anterior divisions of the superior and middle trunks to where the unite to form the lateral cord. confirm that the anterior division of the inferior trunk continues as the medial cord. the lateral and medial cords, formed from the anterior divisions, give rise to nerves contained within the anterior compartments of the arm and forearm. 12 previous next which are the ventral rami of c5-t1 . follow the c5 and c6 roots to where they combine as the superior trunk. follow the c8 and t1 roots start in the neck, and identify the roots of the brachial plexus, tas k

15.1 the brachial plexus iii use the accompanying diagram to work out the answer for this question. what spinal levels contribute to each of the lateral, posterior and medial cords? spoiler alert: the answer is here . make sure everyone in your group understands the answer; use the white board, if it helps. 13 previous next

15.1 terminal nerves of the brachial plexus i the cords of the brachial plexus give rise to the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb. 14 previous next give rise to three major peripheral nerves. place a probe or a finger underneath these cords and nerves to isolate them, and notice that they form the shape of the letter “m” . confirm, on the prosection, that the lateral and medial cords tas k these nerves, with few exceptions , innervate the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, the anterior compartment of the forearm, and the hand, respectively. * take note!! a nerve derived from the brachial plexus does not necessarily take fibres from all the levels contained in the parent nerve. here you see this is true of the musculocutaneous and median nerves. identify the musculocutaneous nerve (c5-c6)* as the continuation of the lateral cord. identify the median nerve (c6-t1)* in the middle , formed by contributions from both the lateral and medial cord. identify the ulnar nerve (c8-t1) as the continuation of the medial cord.

15.1 terminal nerves of the brachial plexus ii the cords of the brachial plexus give rise to the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb. now, gently move these cords and nerves aside and 15 previous next observe that the posterior cord gives rise to the axillary nerve (c5-c6) before continuing as the radial nerve (c5-t1). isolate the posterior cord. tas k follow the axillary nerve around the posterior aspect of the surgical neck of the humerus; its target is the deltoid muscle, the primary abductor of the glenohumeral joint. follow the radial nerve to the posterior aspect of the humerus. it innervates, with no exception, the muscles of the posterior compartments of the arm and forearm.

15.1 branches of the brachial plexus within the axilla i branches arise from the roots, trunks and cords of the brachial plexus that supply the rotator cuff muscles and the muscles of the medial, anterior and posterior walls of the axilla. you are not responsible for identifying any of these nerves, although you are responsible for the function of two, which are described here. 16 previous next two of the rotator cuff muscles, the supraspinatus and the infraspinatus . because the rotator cuff muscles, as a the suprascapular nerve innervates info group, hold the head of the humerus in the glenoid fossa, damage to the suprascapular nerve can cause instability of the glenohumeral joint, and an increased risk of dislocation.

15.1 branches of the brachial plexus within the axilla ii 17 previous next the serratus anterior muscle . because the serratus anterior muscle holds the scapula against the thoracic the long thoracic nerve innervates info the prosected brachial plexus specimen . moisten, wrap and bag tas k wall, lesion of the long thoracic nerve causes “winged scapula” .

15.1 progress check 18 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the pectoralis major and minor muscles, the serratus anterior, subscapularis, teres major, latissimus dorsi, intertubercular groove. to which of the four walls of the brachial plexus does each contribute? what, in general, is contained within the axillary sheath? name of the extension of breast tissue around the inferior border of the pectoralis major. identify the coracobrachialis and tendon of origin of the short head of the biceps brachii. identify the subclavian, axillary, brachial, and deep brachial arteries. what are the superficial veins of the arm? indicate on your own arm where are they located. describe the location and region of responsibility of the humeral, pectoral, subscapular, central, apical and infraclavicular lymph nodes. name the lymphatic trunk that collects lymph from these nodes. identify the roots, trunks, divisions, cords and terminal branches of the brachial plexus. which spinal levels contribute to each of the cords? identify the musculocutaneous, median, ulnar, axillary and radial nerves. which spinal levels are contained in each? describe the effects of a lesion of the suprascapular nerve and the long thoracic nerve. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

15.1 quiz 19 previous you’ve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the end-of-lab quiz now? hmmm, why not? go to the quiz sorry, busy now. i’m setting up a date for tonight. skip the quiz next

15.2 nerves of the arm back to exercise selection resources prosected specimens demonstrating the muscles, nerves and blood vessels of the arm next
when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to describe the distribution of peripheral nerves to the shoulder region and arm. 15.2 objectives 2 previous next

15.2 the approach to learning peripheral nerves 3 previous next the key to identifying peripheral nerves, which can also be applied to identifying blood vessels, is to study them in the context of their surrounding muscles. this is why you learned muscles last week; now that you are familiar with the major muscles of the arm, you will use this knowledge to identify its nerves. once you have identified the peripheral nerves, in the context of their surrounding muscles, their distribution will be more intuitive, and therefore easier to remember.

identify the deltoid muscle clothing the lateral aspect of the proximal shoulder. from last lab, what is the primary action of the deltoid muscle? think first! hint: . answer: arising from the subscapular fossa, identify the subscapularis. notice that it crosses horizontally across the anterior aspect of the humerus to its point of insertion. crossing horizontally from the inferior angle of the scapula to the anterior aspect of the proximal humerus, identify the teres major. the subscapularis and teres major, along with the latissimus dorsi, have one action in common. what is it? think first! hint: . answer . name two other actions shared by teres major and latissimus dorsi . 15.2 muscles of the anterior arm i 4 previous next unwrap the specimen provided. tas k place it on the table as illustrated in the accompanying diagram. it will have the deltoid muscle intact.

15.2 muscles of the anterior arm ii 5 previous next identify the coracoid process, and arising from it, tas k the coracobrachialis and the short head of the biceps brachii. from last lab, what action do these muscles have at the glenohumeral joint? hint: . answer: . identify the long head of the biceps brachii, lateral to the short head. what is the primary action of this muscle at the elbow joint? hint: . answer: . what is its primary action in the forearm? answer: . identify the brachialis muscle, deep to the belly of the biceps brachii. from last lab, what action does this muscle have at the elbow joint? hint: . answer: .

15.2 terminal branches of the brachial plexus i the cords of the brachial plexus give rise to the major peripheral nerves of the upper limb. 6 previous next a characteristic landmark formed by its terminal branches . place a probe underneath the nerves to isolate them, identify the “m” of the brachial plexus, tas k identify the musculocutaneous nerve (c5-c6) most laterally; it is the continuation of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. identify the median nerve (c6-t1), in the middle ; it is formed by contributions from both the medial and lateral cords. identify the ulnar nerve (c8-t1) most medially. it is the continuation of the medial cord of the brachial plexus. and clearly establish that they form the shape of the letter “m”. these nerves arise from the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus. their motor distribution, with few exceptions , are: musculocutaneous nerve: muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, median nerve: muscles of the the anterior compartment of the forearm, ulnar nerve: the intrinsic muscles of the hand

15.2 the musculocutaneous nerve now you will study the relationships of these nerves to the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. 7 previous next distally. follow it as it passes through the belly of the coracobrachialis, which it innervates. trace the musculocutaneous nerve tas k name two actions that would be noticeably weakened by a lesion of the musculocutaneous nerve! think! what are the actions of these three muscles? answer: locate the musculocutaneous nerve where it emerges from the belly of the coracobrachialis to run “like the filling in a sandwich” between the bellies of the biceps brachii and the brachialis. it innervates these muscles, too. trace the musculocutaneous nerve as it emerges from between the biceps brachii and the brachialis lateral to the elbow. it becomes the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm. you learned its distribution in slm 15.1 .

15.2 the median and ulnar nerves in the arm continue your study with these nerves and their relationships to the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm. 8 previous next follow it along the medial border of the belly of the biceps brachii, and into the cubital fossa, the region anterior to the elbow. trace the median nerve distally. tas k trace the ulnar nerve along the medial aspect of the arm toward the elbow. at the elbow, note the relationship of the ulnar nerve to the medial epicondyle: it passes posterior to this bony landmark. the ulnar nerve has no motor or sensory distribution in the arm; like the median nerve, its responsibilities lie distal to the elbow. in the cubital fossa, make note of the relationship of the median nerve to the tendon of the biceps brachii and the brachial artery; the order is tendon, artery, nerve, from lateral to medial. the median nerve has no motor or sensory distribution in the arm; its responsibilities lie distal to the elbow.

15.3 hip flexors and the femoral nerve 3 previous next unwrap the prosected lower limb. place it on the table supine. tas k identify, within the false pelvis, the iliacus muscle, originating within the iliac fossa, and medial to it, the psoas muscle. follow them as they unite to form the iliopsoas muscle and pass deep to the inguinal ligament into the anterior compartment of the thigh. do you recall the action of the iliopsoas? for a hint, click here: identify the femoral nerve located lateral to the psoas muscle. you will not see the formation of the femoral nerve because it is derived from the ventral rami of l2, l3 and l4 in the posterior abdominal wall. notice its position between the iliacus and psoas; here, the femoral nerve gives rise to branches that innervate these muscles. notice that as the femoral nerve approaches the inguinal ligament, it is joined by the external iliac artery and vein. these three structures pass under the inguinal ligament, into the anterior compartment of the thigh, and as they do so, the blood vessels become the femoral artery and vein.

15.3 the femoral nerve in the anterior compartment of the thigh 4 previous next follow the femoral nerve into the thigh; realize that it passesunder the inguinal ligament to enter the femoral triangle. notice that when it passes into the anterior compartment of the thigh, the femoral nerve breaks up to form numerous branches, most of them branches to the muscles of the anterior thigh. the femoral nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment of the thigh, and is therefore responsible for extension of the knee. the femoral nerve does not innervate any muscles distal to the knee. the femoral nerve is cutaneous to the skin of the anterior thigh . where it becomes the femoral artery. notice that the femoral nerve is lateral to the femoral artery. in fact, the nerve is the most lateral structure in the femoral neurovascular bundle; from medial to lateral are the femoral vein, artery and nerve (van). follow the external iliac artery into the femoral triangle, tas k identify, in anterior compartment of the thigh, just distal to the tas k inguinal ligament, the femoral nerve. notice that the femoral nerve is lateral to the femoral artery. in fact, the nerve is the most lateral structure in the femoral neurovascular bundle; from medial to lateral are the femoral vein, artery and nerve (van).

15.3 blood supply to the hip find the deep femoral artery and its branches, the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries which anastomose around the femoral neck. know that these vessels give rise to ascending branches that run deep to the synovial membrane coating the femoral neck to supply the femoral head. they can be damaged in fractures of the femoral neck. 5 previous next

15.3 the femoral artery and the saphenous nerve 6 previous next of the thigh. you may notice that it is accompanied along most of its length by a branch of the femoral nerve called the saphenous nerve. the saphenous nerve is a cutaneous nerve and is the only follow the femoral artery through the anterior compartment tas k branch of the femoral nerve that extends beyond the knee. notice that the femoral artery moves medially as it descends through the thigh. follow the femoral artery through the adductor hiatus into the popliteal fossa, where it becomes the popliteal artery. while it is accompanied through the adductor hiatus by the femoral / popliteal vein, the saphenous nerve remains superficial and passes into the superficial fascia of the medial leg and foot.

the obturator nerve innervates most of the muscles of the medial compartment of the thigh, and is therefore responsible for adduction of the hip. it supplies the medial thigh with sensory fibres . medial to the psoas muscle. you will not see the formation of the obturator nerve because, like the femoral nerve, it is derived from the ventral rami of l2, l3 and l4 in the posterior abdominal wall. previous next turn your attention back to the pelvis. locate the obturator nerve tas k 15.3 the obturator nerve in the medial compartment of the thigh 7 follow the obturator nerve as it skirts the pelvic brim and then passes into the obturator canal . gently, pass a blunt probe through the obturator canal beside the obturator nerve . find the tip of your probe in the medial compartment of the thigh, and use it to help you locate the obturator nerve in this compartment. it usually forms an anterior and a posterior branch.

15.3 the obturator nerve is accompanied by the obturator artery and vein 8 previous next pelvis. the internal iliac artery give rise to branches that supply pelvic organs, but, in addition, it gives rise to three arteries that supply the lower limb. these are the superior gluteal artery, the inferior gluteal artery and the obturator artery. identify the internal iliac artery, a branch of the common iliac artery, passing into the true tas k the superior and inferior gluteal arteries are named according to their position relative to the piriformis muscle; as illustrated, the piriformis arises from the anterior aspect of the sacrum and passes out of the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen. these vessels supply the gluteal region, and are accompanied by nerves and veins of the same name. you will identify these neurovascular structures in a different specimen. in the medial compartment of the thigh. the obturator artery and vein accompany the identify the obturator artery tas k obturator nerve through the obturator canal into the medial thigh.

15.3 the sciatic nerve in the posterior compartment of the thigh i 9 previous next posterior compartment of the thigh. the gluteus maximus is intact in this specimen. inferior to it, identify the hamstring muscles turn the specimen over in order to study the tas k running parallel to the femur. the hamstrings cross the posterior aspect of both the hip and knee joints, and are therefore extensors of the hip and flexors of the knee. separate the hamstring muscles in the midline of the thigh and, between them, locate the sciatic nerve. it is the largest nerve in the body, about the size of your thumb. it contains fibres from the ventral rami of l4-s3.

15.3 the sciatic nerve in the posterior compartment of the thigh ii 10 previous next notice that the sciatic nerve is composed of two divisions, which are the tibial and common fibular nerves. differentiate the tibial nerve by its course through the midline of the thigh and popliteal fossa into the leg. compare this with the common fibular nerve, which swings laterally at the knee, in the company of one of the hamstrings muscles, the biceps femoris. the tibial nerve is largely responsible for innervating the hamstring muscles, and therefore largely responsible for flexion of the knee. while the hamstring muscles contribute to extension of the hip, the primary extensor of the hip is the gluteus maximus muscle, innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. continued…

15.3 there is no sciatic artery! while the sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, it does not have companion blood vessels. the blood supply to the hamstring compartment of the thigh comes from perforating branches of the deep femoral artery. these pass from the anterior compartment of the thigh, through the intermuscular septae and the insertions of the adductor muscles to supply blood to structures in the posterior compartment of the thigh. 11 previous next branch of the deep femoral artery in the posterior compartment of the thigh. identify at least one perforating tas k

15.3 nerves of the gluteal region 12 previous next the superior and inferior gluteal nerves, arteries and veins are named according to their position relative to the piriformis muscle. identify the piriformis muscle, the “key to the region”, passing out of the greater sciatic foramen and running horizontally across the unwrap the prosection of the gluteal region. tas k identify the sciatic nerve passing through the greater sciatic foramen inferior to the piriformis. identify the superior and inferior gluteal nerves and arteries, located superior and inferior to the piriformis . the veins will have been removed from the prosection for clarity. posterior aspect of the hip. what is its action? think, then click ! identify the gluteus medius and minimus. follow the superior gluteal nerve into the plane between these two muscles, running toward the tensor fascia lata. the superior gluteal nerve innervates these three muscles. what actions is it responsible for? think then click ! the inferior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus maximus. what movements is it responsible for? think then click !

15.3 progress check 13 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify and state the actions of the iliacus and psoas muscles. identify the femoral nerve both above and below the inguinal ligament. which spinal levels contribute to the femoral nerve? identify the vessels that accompany the femoral nerve above and below the inguinal ligament. describe the sensory and motor effects of a femoral nerve lesion. identify and describe the distribution of the deep femoral artery, the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, and the perforating branches of the deep femoral artery. identify the saphenous nerve. how does its course at the knee differ from that of the femoral artery and vein? identify the obturator nerve and artery. which spinal levels contribute to the obturator nerve? describe the sensory and motor distribution of the obturator nerve, and the effects of its lesion. identify the three hamstring muscles and the sciatic nerve. which spinal levels contribute to the sciatic nerve? identify the tibial and common fibular divisions of the sciatic nerve. which division is primarily responsible for innervating the hamstrings, and what movement does it therefore control? identify and describe the origin of the perforating branches of the deep femoral artery. identify the gluteus maximus, medius and minimus and the tfl. state the action and innervation of each muscle. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

15.4 distal limb articulations back to station selection resources an upper limb bone box an articulated bony upper limb an articulated bony hand an upper limb joint box lower limb bone box articulated bony foot articulated lower limb a lower limb joint box models of wrist and ankle joints next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to identify and describe the major features of: the articulations of the forearm, wrist and hand. 15.4 objectives part 1 2 previous next joints of the forearm, wrist and hand

15.4 overview of the articulations of the forearm pronation and supination is a movement pair that takes place in the forearm. they involve movement at two uniaxial pivot synovial joints: the proximal radioulnar joint, which is closely associated with the elbow joint, and the distal radioulnar joint, which is closely associated with the wrist joint. in between these two synovial joints, the radius and ulna are joined by the antebrachial interosseous membrane. this membrane serves largely to provide increased surface area for the attachment of muscles that originate in the forearm. in lab 14 you studied the proximal radioulnar joint, in association with the elbow joint. now, in lab 15, you’ll study the distal radioulnar joint, in association with the wrist joint. previous next 3

15.4 the distal radius and ulna notice that it is smaller proximally, and larger distally. at its distal end, identify the radial styloid process on its lateral side, the dorsal tubercle on its dorsal side, and the ulnar 4 previous next take a radius from the upper limb bone box. tas k notice that, in contrast to the radius, it is larger proximally and smaller distally. at its distal end, identify the head of the ulna and the ulnar styloid process. articulate the head take an ulna from the upper limb bone box. tas k notch on its medial side. the dorsal tubercle acts as a pulley around which the tendon of an extensor muscle of the thumb passes. with your own wrist in the supinated position, palpate radial styloid process and dorsal tubercle of your own radius. of the ulna with the ulnar notch of the radius. these are the surfaces that form the distal radioulnar joint.

15.4 movement at the distal radioulnar joint 5 previous next both supine and in the supinated position. the radius and ulna are roughly parallel to each other. lay out the bony articulated arm on the table tas k focus your attention on the proximal radioulnar joint as you pronate and then supinate the bony forearm. notice that the head of the radius pivots in place throughout these movements; i.e. its axis of rotation (red dotted line) is vertical and passes through the radial head. recall that it is held in place against the radial notch of the ulna by the annular ligament. now, focus your attention on the distal end of the radius as you pronate and then supinate the forearm. notice that the distal end of the radius pivots around the head of the ulna from its lateral side to its medial side. the axis of rotation (red dotted line) of the distal radioulnar joint is vertical and passes through the ulnar styloid process.

15.4 structure of the distal radioulnar joint 6 previous next this disc separates the head of the ulna from the proximal row of carpal bones. notice in this illustration that tas k the head of the ulna is held in place against the ulnar notch of the radius by a triangular fibrocartilagenous articular disc. the apex of the triangle attaches to the ulnar styloid process, and the base attaches along the medial aspect of the distal radius. this disc holds the head of the ulna against the ulnar notch of the radius, maintaining the alignment of the distal radioulnar joint.

15.4 the distal radioulnar joint in prosection on the prosection split in the coronal plane, identify the distal radius and the head of the ulna. look for the fibrocartilagenous disc extending across the distal end of the ulna. notice that a coronal section through the wrist demonstrates that the distal radioulnar joint space is “l-shaped” (red arrow). confirm that the fibrocartilagenous disc does, indeed, exclude the ulna from articulating with the proximal row of carpal bones. now that you understand the head of the ulna is isolated from the proximal row of carpal bones, the proper name of the wrist joint will make sense to you. it is the radiocarpal joint. the ulna does not figure into the name, because the ulna does not participate in the articulation. 7 previous next one is sectioned in the coronal plane, the other is sectioned horizontally through the radiocarpal (wrist) joint. from the joint box, take out the two prosections of the wrist and hand. tas k

15.4 bones and joints of the hand 8 previous next the hand is the region distal to the radiocarpal joint. it includes three groups of bones: the 8 carpal bones, the 5 metacarpal bones and the 14 phalanges. articulations are the: radiocarpal joint intercarpal joints carpometacarpal joints metacarpophalangeal joints interphalangeal joints digits ii to v have three phalanges each (proximal, middle and distal), and therefore a proximal interphalangeal joint (pip) and a distal interphalangeal joint (dip). digit i, the thumb, has two phalanges (proximal and distal), and therefore only one interphalangeal joint.

15.4 the carpal bones 9 previous next the names of the eight carpal bones. recall that they are organized into two rows of four bones. using the articulated bony hand provided, review tas k notice that the scaphoid is boat-shaped, with a tubercle extending anteriorly. the scaphoid is the most commonly fractured wrist bone; you will learn how to examine it. identify the crescent-shaped lunate , and the three-sided triquetrum . these three bones form the distal articular surface of the radiocarpal joint. notice that the pisiform is located anterior to the triquetrum. the pisiform is a sesamoid bone that forms in the tendon of the flexor carpi ulnaris. identify the two four-sided bones, the trapezium and trapezoid , the capitate , with a round distal surface, like a head, and the hamate , which has a hook. identify the tubercle of the trapezium and the hook of the hamate, both of which extend anteriorly. these four distal carpal bones articulate distally with the metacarpals of the digits.

15.4 the carpal arch 10 previous next hand and pushing the bones away with the other. in this manner you can see clearly that the carpal bones form an arch that is open anteriorly. cram them together by holding the string in one tas k identify the bony features that form the lateral wall of the arch: the tubercles of the scaphoid and trapezium. identify the bony features that form the medial wall of the arch: the pisiform and the hook of the hamate. the flexor retinaculum, a dense connective tissue band attaches to the lateral and medial walls of the carpal arch to form the anterior wall of the “carpal tunnel” (see below). the bones of the articulated bony hand are strung together with line.

15.4 movement at the radiocarpal joint 11 previous next logical placements of tendons, such that contraction of their associated muscles will cause each of these movements. perform these actions yourself, and think about the the radiocarpal joint is a biaxial synovial joint that permits two movement pairs: flexion/extension and abduction/adduction. muscles that pull across the medial aspect of the wrist will be adductors muscles that pull across the lateral aspect of the wrist will be abductors muscles that pull across the posterior aspect of the wrist will be extensors muscles that pull across the anterior aspect of the wrist will be flexors make sure this is clear to you, because this strategy is the key to remembering muscle actions, rather than memorizing them! going forward, apply this thought process to every joint described; think about where tendons must pull to carry out each action. when you get to looking at the muscles, their actions will make sense. tas k

15.4 structure of the radiocarpal joint 12 previous next identify the articular surfaces that participate in the wrist joint. the proximal articular surface of the radiocarpal joint is the distal end of the radius and the fibrocartilagenous disc that look again at the prosected coronally-sectioned wrist joint. tas k through the radiocarpal joint horizontally. open the joint space and identify the articulating surfaces. notice the shape of the proximal articular surface in three dimensions: it is unwrap the prosection of the hand that has been cut tas k numerous intrinsic ligaments reinforce the fibrous capsule of the radiocarpal joint, including medial and lateral collateral ligaments. as you can see in the accompanying mri, the intercarpal joints share a common synovial cavity (the synovial fluid is white). the fibrous joint capsule is reinforced by numerous, small ligaments. movement between the carpal bones is limited. extend across the distal end of the ulna. notice that this surface is concave from medial to lateral. the distal articular surface of the radiocarpal joint is formed by the proximal aspects of the scaphoid, lunate and triquetrum. notice that this surface is convex from medial to lateral. movement between these surfaces in the coronal plane permit abduction and adduction. ellipsoidal and concave. notice that the distal articular surface is complementary; it is ellipsoidal and convex. movement between these surfaces in the sagittal plane permit flexion and extension.

15.4 flexion/extension at the first carpometacarpal joint 13 previous next notice that the pads of your fingers face anteriorly. in contrast, the pad of your thumb is facing medially. this is because your thumb is rotated around its long axis by 90° with respect to your fingers. place your hand in anatomical position. tas k movement between the distal row of carpal bones and digits ii to v is limited. in contrast, the first carpometacarpal joint, between the trapezium and metacarpal i, is highly mobile. it is important to know the movements of the thumb, as these are assessed as part of the neurological exam, which every generalist performs regularly. shortly, in ice, you will learn how to assess nerve function using these movements of the thumb. flex your fingers: they move anteriorly to curl into your palm. extend your fingers: they move posteriorly. flex your thumb: it, too, curls into your palm, but moves medially to do so. extend your thumb: it moves laterally. because it’s oriented at right angles to the fingers, movements of the thumb are at right angles to comparable movements of the fingers.

15.4 abduction/adduction at the first carpometacarpal joint 14 previous next they pull medially, toward the middle finger. note that these movements occur in the coronal plane. abduct your fingers: they spread laterally, away from the middle finger. adduct your fingers, tas k abduction and adduction of the fingers occurs relative to an imaginary line that runs through your middle finger (digit iii). this is different from elsewhere in the body, where abduction and adduction occur relative to the midline of the body. rotate your hand medially by 90° out of anatomical position, so that the pads of your fingers are facing medially (like your thumb normally does in anatomical position). now abduct and adduct your fingers: they move anteriorly / posteriorly from your middle finger, in the sagittal plane. this is how your thumb moves in abducting and adducting from the anatomical position: anteriorly and posteriorly. rotate your hand laterally by 90° back into anatomical position. the pad of your thumb is now, again, facing medially. abduct your thumb by moving it anteriorly; it is sticking out perpendicular to the rest of your hand. adduct it by moving it posteriorly, back in line with the rest of your hand.

15.4 opposition occurs at the first carpometacarpal joint 15 previous next opposition is a movement that occurs only at the first carpometacarpal joint. the remaining carpometacarpal joints have limited mobility. it involves touching the pad of your thumb to that of another finger. opposition allows us to grip objects in our hand, which we otherwise wouldn’t be able to do.

15.4 the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints 16 previous next metacarpophalangeal (mcp) joints are biaxial synovial joints that allow flexion / extension and abduction / adduction. interphalangeal joints are uniaxial hinge synovial joints. flexion and extension occur at these joints. remember, the four fingers have both a proximal and distal interphalangeal (pips and dips) joints, while the thumb only has an interphalangeal joint. have you thought about how the tendons of muscles must be arranged in order to carry out each of these joints?

15.4 progress check 1 17 previous next since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the features of the distal radius and ulna: the radial styloid process, the dorsal tubercle and ulnar notch; the head of the ulna and ulnar styloid process. in the wrist prosections, identify distal radius, head of the ulna, articular disc, l-shaped joint space, and carpal bones. name, and identify on a bony hand as well as your own hand, the location of the radiocarpal joint, the intercarpal joints (as a group) carpometacarpal joints i - v, metacarpophalangeal joints i-v, and the intercarpal joints. name and demonstrate the movements that occur at each joint. identify the carpal bones and their features that contribute to the carpal tunnel. what structure closes over the carpal tunnel anteriorly? correctly demonstrate flexion and extension, abduction and adduction of the thumb and fingers. correctly demonstrate opposition of the thumb. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

15.4 objectives part 2 18 previous next joints of the leg and foot when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to identify and describe the major features of: the articulations of the leg, ankle and foot.

the tibia receives the body’s weight from the femoral condyles and transfers it to the trochlea of the talus. the fibula does not bear weight but it, along with the interosseous membrane that joins these two bones, provides surface area for muscular attachment. the tibia and fibula are joined by a proximal tibiofibular joint, an interosseous membrane, and a distal tibiofibular joint. the proximal tibiofibular joint is a small plane synovial joint that permits little movement. the tibia and fibula are joined by the crural interosseous membrane, a tough sheet of dense ct. openings in the interosseous membrane proximally and distally allow vessels to pass between the posterior and anterior compartments of the leg. the collagen fibres of the interosseous membrane extend to fill the space between the distal tibia and fibula, forming the distal tibiofibular joint. this joint is reinforced by strong anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments. this articulation is crucial to the integrity of the talocrural (ankle) joint. 15.4 the tibiofibular joints 19 previous next articulate their proximal ends by identifying and matching the articular facet on the head of the fibula with the corresponding facet on the posteroinferior aspect of the lateral tibial condyle. the joint is reinforced by ligaments anteriorly and posteriorly. remove a tibia and fibula from the lower limb bone box. tas k

15.4 bones of the talocrural joint 20 previous next the talocrural joint occurs between the tibia and fibula, proximally, and the trochlea of the talus, distally. it is a uniaxial, hinge, synovial joint that permits dorsiflexion and plantarflexion . lower limb bone box. articulate their distal ends by identifying and matching the fibular groove on the distal tibia remove a tibia and fibula from the tas k in life, these surfaces are held together by ligaments. notice the socket-like articular surface you have created for the trochlea of the talus. identify its lateral border, the lateral malleolus, its medial border, the medial malleolus, and its roof, the inferior surface of the tibia. appreciate that these surfaces are covered by articular cartilage in life. take a bony articulated foot from the lower limb bone box. identify the trochlea of the talus, shaped like a cylinder cut through its long axis. in life, the trochlea of the talus is covered by articular cartilage. articulate the trochlea of the talus with this socket. move the foot through dorsiflexion and plantarflexion. note that the trochlea of the talus is wider anteriorly, and so the trochlea fits more tightly when the foot is dorsiflexed. with the roughened triangular region on the medial aspect of the distal fibula.

15.4 the talocrural joint 21 previous next limb joint box. identify the talocrural joint. realize that the joint is normally enclosed in a fibrous joint capsule that is itself lined by remove two prosected feet from the lower tas k identify the trochlea of the talus and the medial and lateral malleoli. move the joint through dorsiflexion and plantarflexion. identify the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments , which maintain the integrity of the distal tibiofibular joint. the ankle joint is stabilized by medial (deltoid) and lateral ligaments, which maintain the alignment of the joint and restrict its movements to dorsiflexion and plantarflexion. synovial membrane. in this prosection, the joint capsule has been removed, leaving intact its intrinsic ligaments.

15.4 the medial (deltoid) ligament 22 previous next aspect and identify the deltoid ligament. identify its apex, attached to the medial malleolus. identify its fibres fanning out to look at the prosected ankle from the medial tas k the medial (deltoid) ligament gets its name from its shape: it is triangular, like the greek letter, delta, ∆. attach to the navicular, talus and calcaneus. the deltoid ligament is thick and strong. attempt to evert the talocrural joint, and you will see that eversion puts the deltoid ligament under tension.

15.4 the lateral ligament 23 previous next aspect and identify the three ligaments that constitute the lateral ligament. notice that the second part of all three names is “-fibular”, look at the prosected ankle from the lateral tas k the lateral ligament is, in fact, three separate ligaments, each of which can be strained or torn individually, depending on the mechanics of the injury. because all three attach to the lateral malleolus. identify the two “talofibular” ligaments, both horizontal; one is the anterior talofibular ligament, the other the posterior talofibular ligament. identify the calcaneofibular ligament, extending posteroinferiorly from the lateral malleolus. attempt to invert the talocrural joint, and you will see that inversion puts the components of the lateral ligament under tension. the anterior talofibular ligament is the component that is most often injured. one reason is that it is small. however, in addition, we are more likely to invert than evert when we “go over on our ankle”.

15.4 intertarsal joints 24 previous next then on the prosected foot, identify the subtalar joint, the talocalcaneonavicular joint and the calcaneocuboid joint. the first on the bony articulated foot, and tas k latter two joints together form the transverse tarsal joint. it is at these joints that inversion and eversion take place.

15.4 support for the arches of the foot 25 previous next recall that the bones of the foot form medial and lateral longitudinal arches as well as a transverse arch through the heads of the metatarsals . longitudinal arch is the head of the talus. turn the prosected foot over and see that both the medial and lateral longitudinal arches are supported by a dense mass of ligaments . identify only the long plantar ligament and the plantar calcaneonavicular (”spring”) ligament. notice how the spring ligament supports the head of the talus. look at both the bony foot and prosected foot and observe that the “keystone” of the medial tas k you may also see on the prosection that the tendons of extrinsic muscles of the foot cross the sole of the foot to support the arches. a final major structural support for the longitudinal arches is the plantar aponeurosis, a thickening of the deep fascia of the sole of the foot. it extends anteriorly from the calcaneus and forms digital bands that are anchored to the deep tissues of the toes. you will see the plantar aponeurosis in the prosected leg. intertarsal joints between the cuneiforms and between the cuneiforms and the navicular allow only limited movement. the joint between the cuboid and navicular is normally fibrous.

15.4 distal joints 26 previous next the tarsometatarsal joints, plane joints that permit limited movement the metatarsophalangeal joints, which, like the corresponding joints in the hand, the mcps, are biaxial synovial joints that permit flexion / extension and some abduction / adduction; realize that in the foot, abduction and adduction occur relative to the second toe the interphalangeal joints, uniaxial hinge synovial joints that permit flexion / extension as you are now finished with the prosected foot, moisten it, wrap it in a cloth and return it to the lower limb joint box. identify: tas k on both the bony foot and the prosected foot,

15.4 info: bunions 27 previous next hallux valgus, or bunions, develop at the metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe. as the bunion develops, the first metatarsal deviates medially and the hallux deviates laterally. this causes the head of the first metatarsal to become prominent. as the great toe turns toward the second toe, the lateral digits are crowded. bunions are associated with genetic factors, rheumatoid and gouty arthritis, and poorly-fitted shoes.

15.4 progress check 2 28 previous next since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the bony features of the tibia, fibula, tarsals, metatarsals, and phalanges, and the articulations that occur between them. name and demonstrate the movements that occur at each joint. identify the proximal and distal tibiofibular joints and the crural interosseous membrane. identify the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments, the deltoid, anterior and posterior talofibular and calcaneofibular ligaments. identify the bones that form the medial, lateral and transverse arches of the foot. identify the long plantar ligament and the plantar calcaneonavicular (“spring”) ligament. what is their significance? at what joint do bunions develop? how do the positions of the involved bones change with the development of bunions? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next exercise.
